posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone, I’m trying to find a cots pulley from Vex or Studica to run on a dead axle 1+ 1/8 bushing. The only pulley that uses 10-32s has a lip on it, and I’m wondering if it’s dubious to drill out on a lathe. image 750×753 74.9 KB

image 750×753 74.9 KB

image 750×753 74.9 KB

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Two questions:

Why are you basing extra work on screw size?

What’s the diameter of the non-lipped part?

posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked: non-lipped part is 1.125, a press fit to the bushing. The current stack with this pulley is supporting an arm, so I would much prefer to have this run on 10-32s

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Here’s why I asked the second question:

You don’t need to remove that extra part. No lathe boring needed. Just put the bushing in. UNLESS you’re trying to have the bushing go all the way through everything, in which case I would suggest you put up the design of that section for review.

And as for the first question: think very carefully about the design, and the loads. 10-32 isn’t the only bolt size out there, particularly if this is a high-load situation. Maybe look for 1/4-20 sizes instead. I generally suggest designing for loads first, bolt sizes second but sufficient for the load being carried.

posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked: The pulleys from AM are two-sided, so I unfortunately would not be able to put the bushing in on one side, as the other side would likely not be concentric. I’ll look for 1/4-20 sizes instead and hopefully some better options will come up. Thanks!

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
ChiefK33f:

The pulleys from AM are two-sided, so I unfortunately would not be able to put the bushing in on one side, as the other side would likely not be concentric.

That’s why you’d put another bushing on the other side. (Or a bearing.) I wouldn’t assume that they won’t be concentric, particularly if they came off of the same mold.

To answer the original question you had, I’d actually say that a lathe is a decent option, IF you can actually get a concentric grip without damaging teeth. It may take some time, though.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked:
While turning them on the lathe might work, why make it so difficult? Just dremel out the lip and you’re fine. You will still have the 1.125 factory bore on both sides (the outside too) and can then press fit your bushing without any problems. It doesn’t need to be any more difficult than that and taking a burr bit to these pulleys will work just fine.

However, if you don’t mind changing belt types for this, you can also try the RT25 pulleys from Rev (and the corresponding RT25 belts ). These have the MaxSpline bore, which is 1.125 on the inside and has 6 10-32 mounting holes on a 2" bolt circle. We used MaxSpline plate sprockets last year to drive our arm and had a perfect fit with the 1.125 OD bushings that ran on our dead axle, so I know this will work. Just another possibility if you don’t mind a new belt size.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: If there’s so much load that you want to use 10-32s, don’t use a timing belt for the arm. Use something stronger like a sprocket and chain.

posts.name: Keith Farelle Cozart
posts.cooked: I unfortunately will not be able to post the robot but this is a setup for an encoder. it is powered by chain, but the pulley is part of the same bolt stack due a dead axle pivot.
